title: Father Hennepin State Park
text:
Father Hennepin State Park is a <a href="state%20park">state park</a> of <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a>, USA, located on the southeast corner of <a href="Mille%20Lacs%20Lake">Mille Lacs Lake</a>. The park is named after Father <a href="Louis%20Hennepin">Louis Hennepin</a>, a priest who visited the area with a French expedition in 1680. The park has 103 campsites and a sandy beach over one mile (1.6 km) long.
Wildlife.
<a href="Hawk">Hawk</a>s, <a href="osprey">osprey</a>s, <a href="owl">owl</a>s, and <a href="eagle">eagle</a>s are common raptors found in this park. Mammalian tracks of <a href="North%20American%20beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a>, <a href="American%20mink">mink</a> and <a href="deer">deer</a> are often seen by visitors in the soft earth or snow. <a href="Northern%20pike">Northern pike</a>, <a href="walleye">walleye</a>, <a href="bluegill">bluegill</a>s, <a href="Centrarchidae">sunfish</a> and <a href="Bass%20%28fish%29">bass</a> swim around this park's lake. The aspen stands and small clearings are set up for <a href="ruffed%20grouse">ruffed grouse</a>. <a href="Squirrel">Squirrel</a>s and <a href="chipmunk">chipmunk</a>s thrive in maple and oak stands. The small ponds and streams provide homes for amphibians and insects, which in turn attract larger fish, birds and mammals.
Cultural history.
Father Louis Hennepin, a <a href="Franciscan">Franciscan</a> priest of the <a href="Recollet">Recollet</a> order, was dispatched to explore western <a href="New%20France">New France</a> in 1680. Hennepin is not thought to have been in the exact location of the park, but the park is named after him because he was the first to write extensively about the Mille Lacs area. He called the area <a href="Louisiana%20%28New%20France%29">Louisiana</a> in honor of King <a href="Louis%20XIV%20of%20France">Louis XIV of France</a>. In the spring of 1680 he and two companions encountered a group of <a href="Sioux">Dakota</a> Native Americans and were captured, about from today's Father Hennepin State Park. Their release was negotiated eight months later by <a href="Daniel%20Greysolon%2C%20Sieur%20du%20Lhut">Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut</a>. Throughout the experience, Father Hennepin kept a journal describing the lakes, rivers, landscapes, and the lifestyle of his hosts, the Mdewakanton Dakota. In 1683 his writings were published in the book "Description de la Louisiane".
Local advocates and Catholic groups were instrumental in getting the park established in the years before <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The <a href="Minnesota%20Legislature">Minnesota Legislature</a> was reluctant to fund a new park, but when of tax-forfeited land were acquired at little cost, Father Hennepin State Memorial Park was authorized in 1941. However a provision was inserted into the bill barring any state funds from supporting the park for the first five years. County and local funds only went so far, and the park remained largely undeveloped until 1953 when the Minnesota state park system instituted an entrance fee.
